timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Procureur d'office for Canons of St Dié asks local court for investigation of 'sinistres deportemens' of Demenge Mathis, 'prevenu de sortilege et larrecins avec aultres malversations de fort long temps'

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Initial interrogation; said he was about 50, native of Coniche, living as laboureur at Entre-deux-Eaux

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; denied most accusations, made counter-accusations

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; withstood thumbscrews, confessed when racked

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Confirmed confessions, added accomplice Jehennon femme Jean Colin Dieudonné

timeline.subject: Demenge Mathis
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

prior_accusations.context: After her execution as witch, her children said Demenge had been at sabbat

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Mathis (threat to Demenge le Rouyer)
notable_quotes.english: that he would make him sweat

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Mathis (to Vincent Laurent and wife)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il craignoit les rigueurs de la question
notable_quotes.english: that he feared the rigors of torture

notable_quotes.speaker: Son-in-law Demenge Collenat
notable_quotes.french: et luy feroit bailler les estrivieres

notable_quotes.speaker: Didier Simon (describing Demenge)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il a trouvé ledit prevenu fort rigoreux, et de mauvaise conscience, envers ceulx a qui il a heu affaire
notable_quotes.english: that he found the accused very harsh and of bad conscience toward those with whom he had dealings
notable_quotes.context: Description of Demenge's character in tithe collecting

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Jean Dieudonné Laurent (threat from Demenge)
notable_quotes.french: il les feroit aller tout bellement
notable_quotes.english: he would make them go gently/quietly

notable_quotes.speaker: Dieudonné Demenge Collenat (threat from Demenge)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il se teust, et qu'il l'auroit en ung autre lieu qu'il ne se donneroit de garde
notable_quotes.english: that he should be quiet, and that he would have him in another place where he wouldn't be on guard

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Mathis (to Jean Colin Dieudonné about getting rich)
notable_quotes.french: que sy luy deposant vouloit craindre le malgré de ses voisins il ne seroit jamais riche
notable_quotes.english: that if he wanted to fear the displeasure of his neighbors he would never be rich
notable_quotes.context: About putting extra sheaf in tithe stack to cheat

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Gregoire (about Demenge's behavior at Mass)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il adhere plustost au diable qu'a dieu
notable_quotes.english: that he adheres more to the devil than to God
notable_quotes.context: Demenge looked at ground instead of host when priest raised it

notable_quotes.speaker: Marion femme Jean du Treux (threat from Demenge)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il leur gardoit un bon plaisir
notable_quotes.english: that he kept a good pleasure for them

notable_quotes.speaker: Didier Anthoine's wife (about Demenge)
notable_quotes.context: Warning husband to keep Demenge away from house

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Mathis (final statement)
notable_quotes.french: priant au surplus au bon dieu de vouloir avoir pitié de son ame, et luy faire la grace de gaigner son sainct paradis
notable_quotes.english: praying moreover to the good God to have pity on his soul, and to grant him the grace of gaining his holy paradise

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over tithes (accused was tithe collector), land boundaries, theft of animals (geese, sheep), loan collection (6 gros), land purchase from brother-in-law. Demenge described as 'fort rigoreux, et de mauvaise conscience' in business dealings. He sold pair of oxen to have money to flee. Economic value of 100 ecus mentioned for animals lost by Dieudonné Demenge Collenat. Disputes often involved attempts to cheat on tithes by placing extra sheaves in fields.

harms_catalog.harm_description: trouble with feet, one or the other becoming infected and swollen, with discharges, making him cry out with pain; returned annually for 6 weeks around harvest time for about 10 years, now cured
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: boundary dispute between fields; forced to pay 10 francs for wine
Demenge killed two geese that strayed into his field and hid them

harms_catalog.harm_description: second pig became ill, had it killed
fine ox fell sick, had it killed; fearing greater misfortune, went to notary and canceled the purchase note
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: bought land from brother-in-law of accused, who was angry and made veiled threat

harms_catalog.harm_description: finest animal fell down in field when accused was among them; later finest ox became sick, had it killed for fear it would die
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: animals got into field and were eating sprouting corn around last Martinmas
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: immediately (one fell) and later (finest ox sick)

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost fine ox which became emaciated despite eating normally
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: sought reparation from Demenge's son after trespass with cart; settled out of court

harms_catalog.harm_description: ox going lame for 3 weeks before it recovered

harms_catalog.harm_description: young wife died after giving birth

harms_catalog.harm_description: trouble with knee at same season; cat (believed to be Demenge transformed) scratched his knee
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: tied feet of cat doing damage (neighbors said it was Demenge's cat)
tithe dispute 11-12 years earlier; told Demenge to cut whole field at once, Demenge was angry and made threat
after reproaching Demenge that losses followed his threats

harms_catalog.harm_description: mare went blind; a year later died quite suddenly
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to sell mare to Demenge at same price he bought it; asked again a year later, same response
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: a few days later (blind); a year later (died)

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Demenge falsely told her animals were outside their land; told her 'qu'il leur gardoit un bon plaisir'

harms_catalog.harm_description: two more cattle sick, including fine cow given by late father on marriage

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Asked to have people with him in prison so that Persin could not come and punish him; said master had been present in his throat preventing confession

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial shows extensive pattern of economic disputes (tithes, land boundaries, theft accusations) and interpersonal conflicts. Demenge Mathis appears to have been involved in numerous dishonest business practices (cheating on tithes, theft of animals, fraudulent legal tactics). His economic status assessed as 'middling' based on: role as tithe collector, ownership of oxen, ability to lend 6 gros, payment of 10 francs for wine settlement. Multiple witnesses report 20+ year reputation. Notable that son-in-law Dieudonné Demenge Collenat testified against him despite family relationship. Confession under torture names 11 accomplices. Attempted flight before arrest indicates awareness of danger. Some ambiguity about which 'Demenge Collenat' is the brother-in-law vs son-in-law (witness 11 references brother-in-law 'Dieudonné Demenge Collenat' who sold land, while witness 18 'Dieudonne Demenge Collenat' is described as son-in-law - these may be different people or same person with unclear relationship). Regional language: French-speaking area. Trial moved very quickly from initial request (June 18) to execution (July 5) - only 17 days total.
